newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Morocco spends $61.3 mln on industrial zones.
newsitem.headline: Morocco spends $61.3 mln on industrial zones.

text.p: Morocco is spending $61.3 million to build infrastructure in two industrial zones to lure investors and expand local industry, Khalid Kadiri, head of state-run Caisse de Depot et Gestion (CDG) said on Tuesday.
One zone is in the northern city of Tangier and the other in Bouznika on the Atlantic coast near Morocco's fianancial centre of Casablanca, Kadiri said.

"We expect Tangier and Bouznika areas to be among Morocco's leading industrial zones in future...The land will be sold at between 250 dirhams ($27.2) and 400 dirhams per square metre," Kadiri told a news conference held at CDG headquarters in Rabat.
Established in 1959, the CDG fund is mainly involved in banking and construction sectors, he said.
"The fund devoted 490 million dirhams to Tangier's Gzenaya indistrial zone and 74 million dirhams to Bouznika region," Kadiri said.
Bouznika area is now operational while Tangier zone will be ready for industrial projects in 1999, Kadiri said.
Future business and industry projects, including the Tangier area, "should comply with international environment rules...because we want a clean indutrial areas," he said.
Tangier, which is the main financial and industrial zone of a region with five million people, is expected to attract more investors mainly from Spain and southern Europe, officials said.
The European Union plans to invest up to $1.0 billion per year in northern Morocco to upgrade local infrastructure and create new jobs to halt clandestine immigration to Europe.
Morocco, in the early 1960s, built an industrial zone near Tangier's port but its infrastructure failed to meet the increasing demand of industrial investments, official added.
